values:
Dear Mandi, please do not stop posting on LiveJournal.  I promise I will write more often and comment, comment, comment.  Besides, I'm coming to Jacksonville this weekend!  I'll call you, hopefully before you read this.  
I swear it smells like spring outside.  The weatherman said today should be the last of the really cold days here in Pensacola, which I'm glad for.  Sean complained that we won't get a winter, but I think that's what we've been having for two weeks and it was depressing.  My only problem with spring, and eventually summer getting here is that it makes me wish for my Fiat so I can ride with the top down.  I know half of you reading probably think that's silly, but I can dream.  Oh, Mike Prieto if you still read this, I saw Royce Ingram's picture in the Pensacola business paper.  He was in the people-on-the-move section for getting a job at a mortgage company or something.  Funny, huh?  I guess that's pretty much all I have, for now.  Yesterday a customer was in wanting to build a fire pit, and he said, "That is just the cat's meow for me."  I like men who say things like that.  Ok that's all.  Cheers.

Hello friends. I have a few minutes with nothing to do where I can update. I'm at Dad's house, where I came with the promise of BBQ ribs, but am going to end up eating pizza. It's cool. We ordered Socio's Al's Favorite (?) or something. Houston swears it's the best. I vacuumed my car tonight and shined it up with some Armor All so now I'm not ashamed for people to ride in my car. So if you need a ride somewhere, I will come and pick you up. The outside needs to be washed too; I wasn't in the mood to do it this afternoon, but maybe I can trade the three amigos a wash for lunch or a six pack of XX. Speaking of the three amigos, a couple of weeks ago I started taking a Spanish class they're offering at church for free. I'm so stoked about it. I went to the beach by myself again today. I can't explain to you how glorious this is. It's indescribable what's so great about it, but the best part is that there's no one there with me. I don't even feel uncomfortable in my bathing suit, I feel like I look good. You can't buy that. Remember how good my beach mix was the last time I went? Well, today I put my iPod on shuffle, all songs in the entire thing. Up until now I haven't really done that, and I was a little worried that I had so far filled my sweet Pod with things that I don't listen to ever. Or I was kind of afraid that my iPod would pick the crappiest songs in my collection. But I learned that I can trust my iPod to come up with a great mix. It gave me the most chill, relaxed, beach-appropriate mix possible. I feel like my brain's running really fast, too fast for a Sunday night. Pizza's here. I'm going to sit on the couch and eat dinner. I hope Best Week Ever's on. Love you.

One of the good things about being in college is that if you have to do something crappy like go to Wal*Mart to buy groceries, you can usually find someone to go with you. Usually I like Wal*Mart, but having someone with you is infinitely better. There aren't people I can call like that in Pensacola. It's not exactly the same kind of community. I went to the beach today for the first time this summer. I went by myself, which was nice. I made a sweet playlist on my iPod and shuffled it, full of Jack Johnson, the Beach Boys, Stevie Wonder, the Beatles, one Coldplay, one Ben Folds, Seal IV. It wasn't bad, if I say so myself. There was a big family there who sounded like they had an island accent of some sort. One of the men, I guess he was the dad, was chasing the girls around and throwing them in the water; they were fun to watch. And they were wearing neon swimming caps. I had a shower when I came home and watched two Seinfeld episodes while drying off. The day has seemed long and pleasant. I enjoyed lunch with my dad and Houston. I gave Dad a riding lawn mower battery for Father's Day; Houston said every time he mows the lawn he has to jump it. It's a funny present, but I think it made him really happy. He told me about a meeting he had with my mom over the settlement that was upsetting. Two of the most appropriate words for all this are hard and sad. Simply, it comes down to that. But it's much more complicated than that. Please someone help me have more faith. But I'm happy. I'm happy to have gotten sun today. That feels satisfying.

I'm a selfish livejournaler.  I want all of my friends to update, and frequently.  I only update once in a blue moon though; all take and no give.  The thing is I feel like whatever I write on here is going to be worthless and uninteresting.  The other night I was in Wal*Mart, behind a guy in line buying two boxes of votive candles, some deoderant, and some condoms.  All these things make it look like he expected to get lucky that night, but I felt like he would do the word "lucky" justice.  Poor guy.  The same night at the same Wal*Mart someone was walking around leaving their raw meat random places.  Package of raw chicken on the bread aisle, right next to the whole wheat.  A package of bacon thrown in the watermelon bin.  Who would do such a thing?  See, this is all I have.  On the real-life update side, I'm riding with my dad, brother, and husband (last but certainly not least) to Texas for our family reunion.  This is good and bad.  I'm really looking forward to seeing my grandparents, Katie, Aunt Nancy; and it's always fun.  It's bad because I'll be riding for so long in a car with my dad.  But, I have four new books to read, and I'm determined to finish them all while I'm gone.  If you haven't already heard, Sean and I are thinking of moving to Tallahassee so he can finish school at FAMU.  I'm pretty excited about the idea.  In fact, the only thing that makes me apprehensive is finding a new job.  I don't have a career, so I don't even know where to begin looking.  Nor do I know what I want to do.  I thought a bachelor's degree was my window of opportunity to a higher paying job?  They've duped plenty of high school kids with that story because colleges are flooded.  But then post-graduation we realize what the job markets are like in the southeast.  We've been watching a lot of Seinfeld lately, and I've decided that their lives are like being in college.  Always coming over, doing nothing.  And the more I watch, the more I think Jerry Seinfeld and my favorite English professor, Todd Lidh, are alike.  I never realized this in school because I never watched Seinfeld, but I wish I had known.  It would have made Todd even funnier.  I guess that's everything for now.  Peace.  (The mood man is saying 'om'.)

I know this is silly, but I think it feels kind of special when you see things like a bright blue jay, or two fluffy-tailed rabbits hopping on the side of the road.  
Yesterday I had I think the first real conversation I've had with Houston my whole life.  It felt really good.  I wish all of this was over.  Who knows how long it will stretch out.  It's easier for her to do it that way, but it's agonizing for the rest of us.  I'm glad she's finally doing something for herself after all the years of putting us first.  Happy Mother's Day.
There's a lot that makes me happy.  I have more than my fair portion of joy, in small silly things like birds and rabbits.  Those things are my saving graces.  God knows that.  
Sean is also my saving grace.  I couldn't have a better roommate.  He'll make fun of me for being so sappy though.

It's the beginning of summer, when the warm nights smell sweet and you can enjoy being outside.  Tonight big low clouds are rolling and you can hear thunder far away.  I think it's supposed to rain tonight for the first time in forever.  I just hope it's gone by tomorrow afternoon, because I'm going to the beach, finally.  Things are good most days, but maybe one day a week I can't stand under the pressure anymore and I kind of sit down under it.  Or fall down.  This afternoon was one of those.  I feel obligated to make my dad feel better, and when I can't I feel like I'm partly responsible for his feeling bad.  Nothing really makes this feeling go away.  Or allows me to enjoy being around him anymore.  This is a huge shame, as is most of this situation.  Maybe this is stuff I should reserve for my private journal at home, but maybe I want somebody to read it.  Anyway, I think I have to go get dinner ready.  I'll sit outside for a while and enjoy the weather.  Sorry I'm so emo.  (Sean, I put song lyrics in my subject line for you.)

Do you think it's illegal for someone to take a dog into Wal-Mart wearing a fake "Dog in Service" vest?  I don't think the vest was fake; I'm pretty sure this monstrous rottweiler wasn't trained to be a guide dog though.  His owner wasn't using the proper commands and kept referring to herself as Mommy.  That's not very professional.  Neither was his lying down on the job and chewing on his paw.  Anyway, I had a funny run-in with Mr. Johnson this afternoon after work.  He watches Chris, the kid who lives in the house in front of us.  When I slowed down to say hey to him he said, "You look a little different today.  Yesterday you looked like a movie star, you were wearing diamond earrings or something.  You look a little different today."  All I could do was laugh and tell him to have a good afternoon.  This coming from the man who Sean caught "letting his water down" with only his truck to block him from the street.  Oh well.  This isn't an informative update, necessarily.  You probably pretty much know what's going on and why my life is in a shambles.  Thank God for saving my peace of mind, most days.  He's the only possible way I could continue to have hope anymore.  I think I have more to say, but I'm not sure.  I thought I had another pretty good anecdote too, but I can't remember what it is now.  I hope this journal entry finds you well.  I'm going to brush my teeth and go to sleep.  This week's passing too slowly; I thought yesterday was Tuesday, and I feel like tomorrow's Friday.
I wish I lived in St. Augustine because I need two for one drinks at Chili's with my friends really bad tonight.

I went to Jacksonville this weekend with my mom. We just got home and I'm updating from their house because they have a guaranteed internet connection. Mandi, I apologize that I didn't call you. I thought it would be more painful to know we were in the same town and couldn't get together than if you never knew at all. I went over to see Sarah's brand new son, Tate. He's thirteen days old and absolutely beautiful. We had a wonderful time. I wish we lived closer because I don't want to miss anything about his life. I don't have much else to update on, that I can share with everyone who reads, anyway. I've been stressed out about something that I never expected in a million years, and I don't know how to handle it. Over the past couple of weeks I've grown used to feeling a collection of different emotions all in one day. I'm ready for it to be over, but it's not practical to hope that. I do have hope, although it probably looks like it's been attacked by a lion, if you could look at it. I'm tired in many more ways than one. I'm too curious to resist

and when I was there the other day I noticed there's a lady working in the magazine section. I don't like it when she's there; she's very invasive-- asking if you're looking for anything and slamming stacks of magazines loudly on the floor. Doesn't she know the magazine section is just for browsing? No, I'm not looking for anything; I just want to read the magazines in peace. Also, I read this short article in our local Independent News last week: "Researcher Jean-Louis Martin of the Universite Claude Bernard in Lyon, France, found (for a December British Medical Journal article) that consuming cannabis (marijuana) doubled motorists' likelihood of a fatal auto collision, and alarming news headlines about the report followed. Less prominently noted in the article, and consequently in news reports, was that drivers impaired by alcohol were six times more likely than an unimpaired driver to have a fatal collision, thus suggesting that the generally illegal drug, cannabis, is only one-third as dangerous for drivers as the legal drug, alcohol." Speaking of driving, or not, Friday and Saturday Sean and I bought speed bikes at the Helping Hand Mission. They look like they're from the seventies. We've taken spins around the neighborhood on them last night and this afternoon. I'm hoping to work up to riding to and from work. It's definitely close enough, and I think that would be amazing. I'll keep you posted.

I want to write, but I don't really want to say anything.  I want to post pictures, but they're not ready.  But I don't want to be absent for weeks and weeks more without posting.  The wedding was beautiful and fun.  The honeymoon was fantastic, beautiful, relaxing and perfect.  Our new home is nice, and lived-in now.  Please don't ask me how married life is.  I generally hate that question.  I like being married.  I guess we may get the married-people recluse rap because after work and school all the time, the past few months being a little crazy and stuff, I'm so happy to wrap up in my warm house and stay here.  It's quiet, and without the drama of our friends.  Needless to say, I miss Josh Mandi Alyssanne Kelsey more than ever.  You might understand more if you were here with me.  I can't really say what I mean.  Karl, I'm sorry our conversation was cut short the other night.  The battery on the computer died.  I'm not sure how to plug it in.  I was wandering around Target tonight and getting really excited about Valentine's Day.  I want to buy valentines for everyone I know, like in elementary school.  I think I might.  Spread the love.  As I think of more I'll try to post it.  I don't get a chance to do this often.  We're mooching off someone's wireless connection nearby.  Think I'll go read and write some before I go to sleep.  Call me and leave me a voice mail 850 698-5697.
I got a couple of Merry Christmas text messages today only I don't know who they're from.  If it was you, thank you.  I'm blowing you a kiss.

I like this disclaimer about sending text messages via Livejournal: Disclaimer: The reliability of text messaging should not be trusted in dealing with emergencies. As though in an emergency anyone would try to contact anyone through LiveJournal. That's just silly. I don't guess this thought was important enough to merit an entire post, but there it is.

it's hard for me to get into the Christmas spirit this year.  Probably because I'm not at mom and dad's and don't have a tree in my apartment.  and because the pensacola crew isn't the funnest to get into the spirit with.  no home alone, no popcorn and cranberry chains to the tune of elvis's carols.  all I know is that I wouldn't mind going out for a couple of drinks; I haven't done that in too long.  I need some relaxation.  in a glass.  mandi, 'tis the season for dressing up and going out.  btw I was craving one of your chicken sandwiches with the cheese and apples and raspberry jam the other day.  also, I'd like to thank alyssanne for my new userpics.  I ganked them all from pictures she has taken of me surreptitiously and been so generous to share with me.  and now I'm sharing them with you because I like the way she makes me look.  she's one of my favorite photographers.  the restless mood icon looks like someone's attacking him from behind.  they should use that for surprised.

Dear Santa...

Dear Santa,

This year I've been busy!

Last week I gave change to a homeless guy (19 points). In May I turned in for running naked in the mall (3 points). In October on a flight to Colorado Springs, I stole the emergency flight information card (-40 points). Last Tuesday I pulled 's hair (-5 points). Last Saturday I put money in 's expired parking meter (14 points).

Overall, I've been naughty (-9 points). For Christmas I deserve a lump of coal!

Sincerely,
kellileanne

Write your letter to Santa! Enter your LJ username:
Wait wait a minute. Giving change to a homeless guy is 19 good points and stealing the emergency info card on a plane is 40 bad points?? That's bump. Whoever wrote this is obviously more concerned about national safety than helping the poor and needy. In his heart of hearts Santa knows that those pointages have gone awry. He knows I deserve something nice for Christmas. P.S. Sorry Matt.

I discovered tonight that Houston has uploaded Stevie Wonder's The Definitive Collection on his computer, and has quoted it on his AIM profile. All I can say is, attaboy. Now where's that stupid digital camera? I'm sick of those pictures, maybe I can take some better ones while I'm here. Stevie Wonder, Iloveyoukissme!

three o'clock p.m. and I'm ready to go already. this monday has been long. the weather is perfect outside, and sean came to visit me for lunch. I need to make a to-do list of things so I can start marking stuff off. I feel like when you get ready to pack to move someplace- I have so much to do, and don't know where to start. I start one thing, then remember something else and break off in the middle of the thing I'm doing to do what I remembered, and then I forget what I began doing and come back to it hours later. that's what planning my wedding is like. last weekend mandi and kelsey threw me a beautiful shower. we ate outside in fern gully's backyard under the beautiful trees. everything was perfect. I think the best thing about having a shower thrown for you is feeling so special. it's different from being given gifts on your birthday for some reason. mandi and kelsey put so much time and work into my shower, and so many people showed up. it's sobering and humbling to have everyone's care for you concentrated on you all at one time. I felt silly for not realizing and appreciating what these women have done for my heart. during all the introspection I've done trying to get ready to get married, I realized serious relationships are a collaboration of all the people you know. sean and I don't need only each other; we need you too. my thank you could never be big enough. the weather makes me eager for buying a Christmas tree and putting up lights and popcorn and cranberries. oh, and buying new sweaters. I want to put lights on the outside of my apartment, but I think that's against my lease? I'm not sure. I wish you could come visit and help me decorate and put on Christmas music. I want to put pictures of my place on here. I can borrow your digital camera? this entry gets the emo eyes. I think that's what happens when I'm bored and haven't updated in so long. my thoughts are crammed together, and they turn into syrup-y goo. I blame the weather, and my biological clock getting ready for the time change, when I'll have to get out of bed while it's still dark.

I wish I had something nice like fall break to enjoy it. Nope, I have to work tomorrow. Work is lame. Sometimes I wish I worked shift work, where I'd know that my entire day every day wouldn't be wasted. On days like this I want to do physical labor until I'm satisfyingly exhausted and my muscles ache. Or go swimming at the beach. Not crappy lying on the sand, but swimming in the water. Thinks are (sort of) starting to come together, and that's exciting. Sometimes it's weird that this is my life now. I hope this doesn't sound backwards, but I don't want my wedding day to be the best day of my life like everyone says it will be. I want to look forward with expectation. I want this to be the beginning of exciting things happening. Like travel, and productivity. No, I don't mean children. I mean making things that I can be proud of. I'm not sure I communicated what I meant to.
The Potion Maker
kellileannellium is an opaque, acidic sky blue liquid leeched from the lungs of a phoenix.
Mix with kellileanne! Username:
Yet another fun meme brought to you by rfreebern

My LiveJournal Trick-or-Treat Haul
kellileanne goes trick-or-treating, dressed up as Superman.
4minutemile gives you 5 orange vanilla-flavoured gummy worms.
alyssanne tricks you! You get a 3.5-inch floppy disc.
bluechicken tricks you! You lose 3 pieces of candy!
davesawyer gives you 10 brown pineapple-flavoured pieces of taffy.
deadanimalcore tricks you! You lose 9 pieces of candy!
msolomon35 gives you 1 light blue licorice-flavoured jawbreakers.
papitas_fritas gives you 1 light yellow blueberry-flavoured jawbreakers.
themennonite tricks you! You get a rock.
tuesdayiscoming tricks you! You get a wet rag.
wop_n_roll gives you 12 brown pineapple-flavoured pieces of taffy.
kellileanne ends up with 17 pieces of candy, a 3.5-inch floppy disc, a rock, and a wet rag.
Go trick-or-treating! Username:
Another fun meme brought to you by rfreebern.
I'd like to thank Josh Woods, David, Matt, Rita, and Mike for not duping me. To the rest of you, what lame tricks. Except Alyssanne, because that's so you, sweet random hobbit. But at the very least, I finally got to go as Superman with the styrofoam molded muscles, which I've always wanted to do.

Two good things happened tonight. I got my next car payment -which isn't good- but I didn't get charged a late fee which I was expecting. I also got my refund check from paying that jerk at Pop-a-Lock in St. Augustine. Tomorrow after work I'm driving to Panama City to support the band as they play at FSU's BCM retreat. I hope it's fun; I think it will be. OK. Here's a playlist from Paul McCartney's perfect show last Saturday night (Mandi, Paul's shirt makes me look prettier. I wore it Wednesday night and got many compliments, not on the shirt itself but on how nice I looked): Magical Mystery Tour Jet I'll Get You in the End Drive my Car Til There Was You Let Me Roll It Got to Get You into My Life It's a Fine Line Maybe I'm Amazed The Long and Winding Road If You'll Be True To Me I Will Jenny Wren For No One Fixin a Hole Cup of English Tea I'll Follow the Sun Follow Me Blackbird Elenor Rigby Too Many People She Came in Through the Bathroom Window Good Day Sunshine Band on the Run Penny Lane I've Got a Feeling Back in the USSR Hey Jude Live & Let Die -Encore- Yesterday Get Back Helter Skelter Please Please Me Let it Be Sargent Pepper The End I don't even have to say how amazing it was to be in the same room as Sir Paul McCartney, Beatle amazingextraordinaire. I'm so happy we went, and consider it money very well spent. I decided that night of Paul Day that life is made up of moments. You cannot live in hope of the future, or in memories of the past. What you have is this moment, right now, to enjoy. I know this sounds said-before, but I think it's a verson of carpe diem in which, whatever it is, you should do it.

As if I have to be reminded. Today is Friday for me. Yesterday when I came home from work, the side yard had been mowed, all the leaves blown out of the carport, and the trash can moved to the street. And my neighbor Monty is out of town. I can only attribute this to my freaky landlord. In the contract he says we can pay him some extra money for his guys to do yard work, but I didn't ask him to so I hope he doesn't try and charge me for it. A couple of weekends ago (and I don't know how I forgot to write this), Sean, Ian and I were driving around downtown. Underneath the interstate in a big field, a black man had parked his Mustang. The door was open on the passenger's side and loud jazz music was blasting out. This is the best part: He had his shirt off, and was accompanying the jazz music with his own trumpet. And he was pretty good. I think he was wearing a cab driver hat too. I wanted to meet him and talk with him, but how weird is that? Walking up to someone playing their trumpet out in a field. I think he wanted to be alone. I should probably get to work. This is kind of a nerdy plug, but tonight is the grand opening of an exhibit at the T.T. Wentworth Museum on women in Pensacola during the twenties and thirties. I think it will be very interesting, and a friend of mine has been working on this project for a long time and is really proud of it. On a different note, there will be a band called Luna Mantra playing at the Belmont Arts Center tonight. I think I'm going to miss it, which disappoints me, but I think you should go. Cheers.

The UPS man noticed again yesterday that my hair is growing. He probably meant to say it's overgrown. The weather is duping me. It looks cool and fall-like, but it's hot. I meant to post yesterday and say 'Happy Birthday love' but I was too busy to post yesterday. Happy Birthday love.

I'm ready to open the windows and enjoy the smell and cool breeze of fall. I smelled the change in season on Friday afternoon. It was a tease, naturally. But I'm so ready. I've got to find something to make this Labor Day worthwhile. It's slipping away. I don't have any ideas. Ice cream sounds good, though. Maybe I'll go shopping for a duvet cover. I know that doesn't sound fun to any of you. Maybe you, Mandi. I've been really missing you this week, MandiAlyssanneJoshKelseyKellyBecky. I wish I was living with you in a big commune in Chattanooga. Or a small commune, really. I don't have much worth updating. This was fun: Last weekend Sean, Allen and I enjoyed a cigar downtown, and after that we went to Krispy Kreme to sit at the bar and drink coffee and milk and eat donuts. There was an old man sitting further down the bar, going through what looked like receipts jammed in his wallet and reading them aloud to himself. After a while he started talking to us. For a mental picture, he looked like the father from Big Fish. He started to tell us stories about working in a port in Biloxi growing up, and about World War II. Most of the stories had to do with liquor and how much he had on his ship in particular. He told us not to mix liquor with Pepsi because it's not any good. He must have talked for at least an hour. He was cracking himself up, too. I loved him. (The man has a halo over his head, but I don't feel 'good' like that. I feel good, comfortable, happy, content, pleased, like I should be lying in sweet grass and clover with my shoes off. If that man's face looked like mine, his eyes would be closed and he would be smiling as if he were smiling in his sleep.) Click here.
Take the quiz.
Post your results.
1) Would go out with ? I'm betting not.
2) Where did you first meet ? Olive.
3) One quality you find attractive in ? holy smoke. his sense of humor.
4) How many monkeys could fight at once and win against? probably five.
5) If took over the world, who would be happy? probably everyone, but alyssanne first and foremost.
6) Is an emo? nah
7) What rank would have in a giant robot army? second in command.
8) Which president would be likely to idolize? Ronald Reagan
9) Where was born? Texas. Corpus Christi? no, that's not right. I don't remember what city.
10) Is popular? no, by choice I think.
11) How would conquer the world? he'd hack into its mainframes and make it implode.
12) Do you have 's screenname? out of the twenty-five, I don't know which one he's currently using.
13) Have you ever dated ? yes.
14) What do you agree with about? lots of things. frisbee. tattooes. movies.
15) How long would dating last? hypothetically if they were gay and not married? I'd give it a few months, four maybe.
16) If commanded an army, who would be his/her followers? Stacy will be president someday, so it'll be every branch of the armed forces.
17) Is a high school student? no. well, kind of now that he's teaching it.
18) Does have a crush on ? no, but she might if she met her.
19) Are and going steady? no.
20) Does travel a lot? no.
21) What animal does remind you of? he makes me think of a rabbit, because of his icon.
22) Is athletic? I'm laughing out loud.
23) When did you last call ? never.
24) Would be a better ninja or pirate? pirate.
25) 's hair color? black.

the longer and longer I wait to update about the best Best Weekend Ever, the more it slips away from me. but I don't feel like writing about it. I don't have any cool pictures to show for it like my friends do.

"I've moved my card table to the front window with the telescope beside it so if anything goes on I can tompeep it.  Two seagulls right now trying to walk on the ice and falling through every few steps and then looking around to see if anyone noticed.  I have a feeling that seagulls hate to be laughed at.  Well, who doesn't, for that matter?"
John Steinbeck to Elizabeth Otis, Sag Harbor, January 3, 1957 "(I think it is Jan. 3, pretty sure in fact.)"

I like interesting addresses; ones with personality, not "Smith Street" or anything.  I've lived at a couple of pretty good ones:  8151 Cayuga Trail, Sycamore View, #9 Leighcliff, Ponitz Parkway.  Now I have a new one, and it's pretty good:  1017 1/2 B DeVilliers Street.  Without a doubt, Sean and I have the best, most interesting place to live out of all our friends.  We don't own it like they own theirs, but somehow that feels even better.  It reminds me of Steinbeck's traveling and the expatriots living on the West Bank of Paris during the war.  Temperoray-ness feels good right now, because I don't necessarily want to settle in Pensacola for a long time.  

Please come visit, it's absolutely beautiful.

"You said that this was my home but I have thought about it deeply.  I have no 'place' home.  Home is people and where you work well.  I have homes everywhere and many I have not seen yet.  That is perhaps why I am restless.  I haven't seen all of my homes."

John Steinbeck
October 14, 1949
Friday night

This weekend's going to be great.  Sean is planning the best birthday surprise ever for me tomorrow, and Sunday Mom and I are going shopping in Destin.  I'm looking forward to spending some free time with her; we haven't gotten a lot lately and we're getting on each other's nerves.  Maybe I can catch David between parties and actually hang out with him while he's in town.  And I don't have to work Monday, but I get paid anyway.  I have a lot to look forward to.  So far I don't have any actual plans for the Fourth though.  I would love love to go to the beach tomorrow to watch the Blues fly, but oh well.  I'll be doing something better.  I guess; I don't know what it is yet.  Anyhow, have a good one.

I had some depressing things to write on here earlier today.  Complaining.  That was stupid.  Because it was about not anticipating birthdays anymore, and it was cynical.  I had so many pleasant surprises today.  I think...  about seven.  Probably more.  They made this Monday definitely worthwhile.  My place to live has fallen through, temporarily.  As for my weekend, Friday night was lame; Saturday night was way more fun than I expected it to be; and Sunday, tho I feel guilty about it, I enjoyed some rest.  
     I wish you could give me some feedback.
     I also wish I could scan in my notes, so you could read them as they were first written:  in my handwriting.  I might even doodle on them, Mandi.

I'm sad my birthday's over.  What a good day.

I haven't considered myself in with my boss so far, (except when we all went to dinner and everybody said 'Nobody puts Baby in a corner!' and called me Baby for the rest of the night), but today a truck driver came in who had the most amazing mullet and while I was standing close to Scott I said, "Holy mullet" under my breath. I think he laughed until he had tears in his eyes. Then we started to talk about The Wedding Singer, which we both consider an underrated comedy. Then he invited me to lunch! Note to self: Establish yourself on same ground as boss. Obviously we like the same movies. This is my in, and my road to a raise. I found a place for my mom and me, and then Sean and me, to live. It's a duplex; it has two bedrooms and two bathrooms with a big living room, fireplace, and nice carpet. There's nothing really charming about it, especially outside, but I think it has potential. And it's really inexpensive. I'm nervous and excited. I can move in right away, which is what I'm nervous about. I've never wanted to live alone. This is the first place we looked at, which is one less thing I have to drive around and worry about. Thank goodness. I wasn't kidding earlier this week when I said I needed to unwind this weekend. I don't know why. Nothing has been particularly stressful or demanding. I just want to relax and have a good time. And not be at home. It's kind of ridiculous to see two grown men having a conversation with their heads up a fireplace so they can look at the damper. I heard on NPR yesterday that a 73-year-old man killed a leopard that was attacking him by pulling its tongue. I want to know how he did that without losing his arm.
Something about being at work the past two days is making me stir crazy.  And I feel lethargic and bleh.  I need something to shake these blues.

I should be in bed right now because I won't want to wake up in the morning, but I'm not tired because I drank some coffee not too long ago.  I also drank some peach flavored vodka, which tasted like the most awful medicine you can imagine being forced to take.  I also drank some raspberry flavored beer that was nice and smooth, but whose name I don't recall.  It sounds gross, but it didn't taste sweet or anything; it was just nice and amber.  Today Sean and I drove through Starbucks to use my gift card, but the girl in the window knew Sean, so she gave me my drink free.  She was super cool and I've only met her once.  

Alyssanne, Josh's dates off are 24-26 June, 8-10 July, and 22-24 July from Saturday around 2pm to Sunday around 1pm.  That's a pretty small window.  We'll figure something out, I hope.  Becky told me he's coming there for a week before he leaves the country.  I'm furious.

St. Augustine, being away from you is killing me.  You know who you are.  I'm not 100% the same without you.

Did You Know?
One of my greatest joys in life is granola in yogurt.  (Don't try it at Wendy's-- it's disappointing.)
I like summer showers, especially when they turn into storms.
I love looking at office supplies, especially pens, but prefer writing with ultra fine point Sharpies.

There's been a lot of down time at work today, but it's been pleasant, not boring.  Today a customer came in who looked like an American Indian and a Mexican.  And accuse me of stereotyping, but I didn't really expect him to speak English.  When he spoke I was shocked, because he had the most redneck, country accent.  "Naw, a kyooob.  C - O - uh, U - B - E.  [to me:] 'at rahyt?"  Whoah.  This man was a walking contradiction.  Also, today I was searching for someone on thefacebook whose name has J-U-D in it.  The search pulled up anyone whose name was Judy, which I found out is wildly popular with Asian parents.  Who knew.  Try it and see how many come up.  I always thought of Kim as a popular Asian girl's name.  Guess I was wrong.

My little brother graduated from high school tonight.  I'm really excited for him, but I know that what he's going to do in college and after that will be much greater than what he has already done.  That goes for you too, Nadia.  Congratulations!  I love you.

soft old shirts are love

I think my new haircut makes me look more like a fairy than I already did. Unless you think this picture doesn't look like me at all.

Mandi, I found this amazing original record of Paul's in my parents' collection when we moved my cabinet stereo turntable into the living room.  I immediately thought of you.

I can't write down what I feel, right now, today, or yesterday.  Saturday afternoon I felt like my heart was just broken.  I had to drive away from the people who have been my family, and who are moving out and graduating and scattering.  They're all going to chapter camp next week together and I feel hot, bitter jealousy and sad pain.  All I want is to be with you right now.

At the same time I'm feeling all of that, I bought a new car last night.  She's beautiful and red and peppy and I love her.  She's un-named so far.  I saw my old sweet Beretta in the church parking lot, which was also a little sad.

I'm sick of this week and its ups and downs.

If you think I can pull off driving a 5 speed, 150 hp, 1.9 liter turbo engine, red Beetle, comment saying fudgesicle. If you think I can't pull it off, comment with mayonnaise. If you're on my friends list and you don't comment on this post, I'll kill you.

Today while sitting at a light I looked at the Mercedes Benz next to me, and a really distinguished-looking black man in an expensive suit was waving at me.  Also, the UPS guy noted that my hair was growing.  Work is made up of countless fragmented, mini-relationships like that with people you talk to on the phone but never see, or customers whose names you don't know.
*
Last week Dad sold my car without even trying, and he got a deal for it- way more than the Kelly blue book trade-in value of it, which was $260.  I was sad to see my babygirl go.  She was my first car.  Dad and I are going to look at cars on Saturday.  I'm nervous because I've never haggled for a car before.
*
 I'm sad about the changes that are coming up.  Kelsey and Josh are graduating and moving away; Josh completely out of the United States.  And Kelly, Mandi, and Alyssanne are moving out of Tardmont, which means things will be seriously effed up when I visit St. Augustine from now on.
*
Sean surprised me with tickets to see James Taylor next Sunday night, only to find out he has to play that night and can't go with me.  I have two tickets to see James Taylor, and I haven't decided what I'll do yet.
*
I got a raise today because now I'm officially on payroll at W.R. Taylor & Co.  No, I don't lay brick.

You're Canada!
People make fun of you a lot, but they're stupid because you've got a much better life than they do.  In fact, they're probably just jealous.  You believe in crazy things like human rights and health care and not dying in the streets, and you end up securing these rights for yourself and others.  If it weren't for your weird affection for ice hockey, you'd be the perfect person.
Take the Country Quiz at the Blue Pyramid

And I officially want a tan. I call the refrigerator at work the refrigerator of death, because that's what it smells like. And yesterday Tina and I found out why. I always bring my lunch and keep it in there, so I know that it smells awful. Tina normally doesn't, but yesterday she did. She opened it and smelled the death smell and we both exclaimed over how nauseating it was. Well she had the courage to look around and try to figure out what was causing it. I usually just close the door as fast as I can. She spotted a tin foil package, and suspected it right away. Upon opening it, we discovered a lump of raw, green, and rotted meat. It belongs to the Mexicos. This is why I've been saying that it would be worth it to send them to a food safety preparation class. We're all going to get E. coli. Javier was sweet enough to buy me a coke, though. He buys Tina a diet coke every day. Yesterday I was sitting back at her desk when he came in for lunch. We hear him go into the kitchen and put a dollar in for Tina's diet coke. Then he puts another dollar in and stands for a really long time, as though deciding what to get. Finally he presses a button, and brings them both out to us. While the yard manager Kenny is gone, Javier and all the amigos have been calling Tina patron, which means boss. They're great.

Josh sent this to me in an email, and in order to make more people aware whose email address I might not have, I'm posting it.  Please take some kind of action.
__________________________________________________________________________


I wanted to let you all know of a situation that, I think, demands our attention.  Currently in the country of Sudan, there are Arab Muslim militias, backed by the government, that are raping and killing African Christians and animists in the Darfur region of the country.  So far, about 100,000 are dead and at least 2 million have been displaced from their homes and villages.  Recently, the US Congress has officially called this situation a "genocide."  Officially calling a crisis by that name gives our country a legal responsiblity to stop it.  
 
A national campaign, called 100 Hours of Conscience, will begin on March 17 with a moment of silence at 3pm.  The following four days will be a time for national prayer and attention to be brought to the situation in Darfur.  The campaign is also encouraging people to write letters to President Bush and their members of Congress to enourage them to take action to stop the killing in Sudan and to help stablize the region.  Sample letters and mailing addresses for representatives can be found here.  For more information on what is happening in Sudan and what to do about it, go to www.savedarfur.org.
 
I would like to invite you to join me in prayer during these 100 hours and to write to our representatives in government.  Also, please feel free to forward this information to anyone else who may be interested in urging our leaders to stop this genocide.
 
Thank you,
Josh Reynolds
_________________________________________________________________________

How many times must the cannon balls fly before they're forever banned?
Bob Dylan

I write stuff down all day every day to post on livejournal, and I usually throw the paper away.  An overwhelming number of people have requested that I update more often, so I'll start posting what I write on those papers during the day.  Maybe I'll even post more than David, who should be writing his senior thesis instead of posting on livejournal.  It's too bad I can't post my doodles, too.  Mandi you would be in Heaven.  Don't be fooled, though.  This is no pie in the sky by and by.  (A little inside, I know.)  

At work we use an operating system from 1989.  That should be enough said, but there's more.  When you open an order and then decide to close it without saving, you press F5, which brings up a message that says, "Warning:  You have chosen to kill this order.  F5 to KILL."  

Today I saw a person who was either a man dressed as a woman and not remotely trying to disguise his voice, or a woman whose hormones are sadly screwed up.  I think it was a man.  When a man dresses in drag, you expect him to be wearing heels and fishnets, right?  This guy was dressed as a middle age woman who wears denim shirts with potted flowers embroidered on them.  It was strange, and I think I had to deliberately not visibly react with my face when I heard him speak. 

Also today they had to fire Duke, one of the drivers who delivers our brick all over town.  He failed his drug test for using marijuana and cocaine.  This makes me really sad because Duke always made me smile, and was one of the last people I would suspect was doing drugs.  I missed seeing him at work already this afternoon.

Today is a stunningly beautiful day. I can't wait to get off of work. Tomorrow a group of kids is going to Laura Davis' parents' home in Blountstown to spend the night and eat some great food. You're right, David, it's in Florida not Alabama. My bad. Monday is Valentine's Day. I don't have any plans so far. I do have some gift ideas, though. For Sean, not me. I always think of things to post on LiveJournal during the day, and sometimes I write them down but I usually throw the paper away and now I can't think of anything to write. Go figure. I'm at W.R. Taylor for two more weeks. They have a position open. I don't know if they'll offer it to me or not. I don't really know what I'll say if they do. It would be smart for me to take it. I went to Mobile for Mardi Gras when Linsey was in town with Sean, John, Darren, and Monica. It was so much fun. We saw an afternoon parade in Pritchard, Alabama where we were definitely in the minority. People kept asking us to take their picture or pictures of their babies, and one lady said we looked French. When we told her we were actually Floridian, she said well, we are too white and we need to get tans. I thought the night parade in Mobile was not as fun because we didn't get to talk to any interesting people, but it was pretty exciting. I haven't developed my film yet so I don't know if I got any good shots, but Sean and John took a lot of really great pictures. Hopefully I can share a couple of them if I can get copies on a compact disc (ahem). Well I guess technically I shouldn't be doing this on company time, so I'm out. Have an awesome weekend.

Now that I'm working downtown again, all four members of my family are up early in the morning and get to share a certain amount of family togetherness before our days begin.  For example, this morning our suburban wouldn't start, so I got outside to help my dad push it down the driveway.  Putting us down to two cars, we also get to spend extra time together in the car while taking one another to work and school.  In all seriousness, my car is not working in the driveway and now the suburban, and I feel terrible for Dad.  He works manual labor all day and doesn't feel like getting underneath cars when he gets home.  I wish there was some way we could be blessed with two cars that work properly at least most of the time.  And that's your early morning update from the Neff household.  I hope you're having a beautiful day.

Waiting for a package to come in the mail when you're expecting it is the worst thing. A week ago I drove to Hotlanta to meet Josh, Becky, and Mandi for the year's best sledding trip. We decided to call it our summer vacation instead because it was so hot. We had a great time visiting Chatanooga, and we decided that we all want to live there. We went to the High Museum and saw a beautiful Van Gogh exhibit. I picked up a few good CDs and a couple of good books while I was there. Most of all I had a great time with hanging out with the pack. There were a lot of hilarious details that I deliberately tried to remember, but I forget them now. The day I drove home my car broke down in La Grange, Georgia. My alternator was bad and sucked the living daylights out of my battery. A really nice guy named Norman stopped to help me push my car out of the middle of the road. He ended up offering to just change my alternator on the side of the road because it was too late in the day for any car place to take me. My parents nearly had a heart attack when they found out I got in the car with him, but I ended up being blessed by the testimony of the way God has directed his life. What was the most compelling about him was how he was concerned that I know the love of Christ and that God would always be real in my life. I don't think I've heard anyone speak so strongly to me about his desire for God in my life, and he was a perfect stranger. I hope there are many more honorable and godly men out there who will help a girl in her time of need. Mandi, you don't think we can convince Becky to start a LiveJournal, do you? I bet hers would be the bomb.

If you think of me tonight or tomorrow please pray as I go to the jewelry store.  This is my one big hope for a job, and without it I'm not sure where I'll go from there.  Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

Mandi, I smiled when I got your text message tonight because earlier I was listening to "She is His Only Need" by Wynonna and I thought of you.  I found your picture on my computer today, too.  I had no idea it was there and it was a wonderful surprise.  I love you, and I miss you.
